quotes.quote: Deadlines and things make you creative.
Deadlines just aren't real to me until I'm staring one in the face.
A deadline is negative inspiration. Still, it's better than no inspiration at all.
You put deadlines on people you really don't want, because that's how you feel about them.
Meeting external deadlines is much harder than meeting internal ones. On the other hand, internal deadlines sometimes don't feel real, and are therefore easy to evade.
At some point, you have to sit down and face the page alone. At some point, the final decisions need to be yours. At some point, you have to give yourself deadlines and stick to them.
Be able to meet any deadline, even if your work is done less well than it would be if you had all the time you would have preferred.
As you schedule individual tasks, give yourself a cushion. Mark the due date a few days ahead of the actual deadline so you have time to deal with changes or last-minute emergencies.
Like all writers, my greatest inspiration, my ultimate muse, is a deadline.
Give yourself a deadline to stop planning and to start taking action.
With the movies, people are not going to wait around. The deadline is a deadline. In publishing it's more a polite suggestion.
A journalist is stimulated by a deadline. He writes worse when he has time.
Deadlines aren't bad. They help you organize your time. They help you set priorities. They make you get going when you might not feel like it.
Everything is an experiment until it has a deadline. That gives it a destination, context, and a reason.
Deadlines refine the mind. They remove variables like exotic materials and processes that take too long. The closer the deadline, the more likely you'll start thinking waaay outside the box.
The pathology of setting a deadline to the earliest articulable date essentially guarantees that the schedule will be missed.
Meeting the deadlines is not good enough, beating the deadlines is my expectation.
Goals aren't enough. You need goals plus deadlines: goals big enough to get excited about and deadline to make you run. One isn't much good without the other, but together they can be tremendous.
If we didn't have deadlines, we'd stagnate.
The moment you put a deadline on your dream, it becomes a goal.
Deadlines concentrate the mind. But deadlines should not be dogmas.
Today we often use deadlinesâ€”real and imaginaryâ€”to imprison ourselves.
A harsh reality of newspaper editing is that the deadlines don't allow for the polish that you expect in books or even magazines.
Empower your dreams with deadlines.
Deadlines are things that we pass through on the way to finishing.
Deadlines comes as a surprise....superb: a new genre, in fact, combining the pleasures of list-making with that of last-minute eaves-dropping.
A goal without a deadline is just a dream.
Deadlines are meant to be broken. And I just keep breaking them.
Without deadlines and restrictions I just tend to become preoccupied with other things.
Inspiration is for amateurs. professionals work everyday. Personally the best inspiration is a deadline.
A goal or decision without a deadline has no urgency. It has no real beginning or end.
There's a lot of reasons why deadline-driven may actually - it's not necessarily a bad thing, it just all it does is it speeds up and makes you a little proactive about decision making.
Publishing is, by its nature, about deadlines, and deadlines are toxic.
GOALS are dreams with deadlines, and without those deadlines, our dreams are dead in the water.
Deadlines have a lousy name. Call them live-lines instead. ThatÂ´s what they are.
I've learned over decades of building that a deadline is a potent tool for problem-solving.
